title: English (1752) Douay-Rheims (Challoner) Bible - Vol.1-2
description:
The Douay-Rheims Bible, revised by Richard Challoner, is a pivotal work in the history of English Bible translations. Originally translated from the Latin Vulgate and first published by the English College at Douay in 1609, it underwent several revisions by Challoner:

1749: The first revision of the New Testament, incorporating changes from the 1738 edition by Richard Challoner and Francis Blyth.
1750: The first revision of the Old Testament in two volumes, followed by the second revision of the New Testament in one volume.
1752: The third revision of the New Testament in two volumes.
1763 - 1764: The second revision of the Old Testament in four volumes.
1764: The fourth revision of the New Testament.
1772: The fifth revision of the New Testament.

This work also saw several notable editions:
1790: The first American edition, based on Challoner's Second Edition (1763-64), published in Philadelphia by Carey, Stewart & Co. in two volumes.
1796: A four-volume edition published in Edinburgh by John Moir.
1942: The New Testament, as revised by Dr. Challoner in 1752, published in New York by The Douay Bible House. This edition was praised by the Pope as the best text in the American tradition.

These revisions and editions reflect the enduring impact of Challoner's work, making the Douay-Rheims Bible more accessible and understandable for English-speaking Catholics. The Douay-Rheims Bible, especially the Challoner revision, continues to hold significance in religious studies and practices.
